section.name: Accounting of purchase, prepayments, payments tracking, bank reconciliation.
section.p: Keywords: Accounting of purchase, prepayments, sales taxes from purchase, payments tracking, bank reconciliation.
section.h4: Sales taxes that is payed on a purchase of raw materials (producing USA).
section.p:
According IRS 535 Business Expenses, Page 18 sales taxes that Bob pays on purchase of materials are business expenses (sales taxes are included into material cost), i.e. they are deducting income tax:
... Any sales tax you pay on a service for your business, or on the purchase or use of property in your business is treated as part of the cost of the service or property. If the service or the cost or use of the property is a deductible business expense, you can deduct the tax as part of that service or cost. If the property is merchandise bought for resale, the sales tax is part of the cost of the merchandise. ...
That is sales taxes from purchase is included into inventory and they become expenses automatically as part of Cost Of Goods Sold (method FIFO in this case). So Bob should set accounting settings "Extract sales taxes from purchase" to No, and set "Enabled" to No for "Entries source" #4 "Purchase invoice. Debit Sales tax from purchase per tax, Credit Payable per vendor for tax amount.":
Also he should set "Enabled" to No asset account Sales Tax From Purchase.

If you have to use different method to account sales tax from purchase, then set accounting settings "Extract sales taxes from purchase" to Yes, and set "Enabled" to Yes for method #4 "Purchase invoice. Debit Sales tax from purchase per tax, Credit Payable per vendor for tax amount." Then you should set "Enabled" to true asset account Sales Tax From Purchase. Also you should add sales taxes, item tax categories and set tax category for goods/service (see Accounting of sales, prepayments, payments tracking.) You are able to change tax amount in a purchase invoice line (item basis and aggregate/only rate) or total invoice (invoice basis). In USA extracting taxes from purchase (from item's cost) is required in case of using "inventory capitalized costs" method (see IRS 538, Page 18 Uniform Capitalization Rules). Capitalized cost becomes an expense partially, depending on ending inventory (final product).
For many other countries sales taxes (e.g. VAT, GST) from purchases are always extracted from goods/service cost, and they deduct themselves (taxes from purchases deduct taxes from sales).

When bank account balance in your accounting system (software or book) is not same as in the bank (in the bank statement), then you have to make adjusting entries. This is called "bank reconciliation". For example, yesterday you received a check for 500USD from customer "Firm A" and made this accounting entry:
Debit CashInBank.Account#243443354 for 500USD Credit AccountsReceivable.FirmA for 500USD
After that your bank account balance is 10000USD (in your accounting system). Today you received the bank statement that is saying that the check was rejected, and you was charged for 10USD additionally cause that "wrong check", and the balance is 9490USD. So you have to make two adjusting entries:
Credit CashInBank.Account#243443354 for 500USD Debit AccountsReceivable.FirmA for 500USD Credit CashInBank.Account#243443354 for 10USD Debit Expenses.BankExpenses for 10USD
